body: @reminisce

I have a question about the mean_img used in this feature extract program ,I get the mean image from here http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/data/Inception.zip and use the model provided in the README but I think the  mean_img  should be the RGB style but in the feature extract program I think there is no convert for the pictures to the RGB style just use the BGR ,also https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/predict-cpp/image-classification-predict.cc in this program they did the convert
File name changed.
I meet the same problem as you, do you find the method to solve it ?

I ran depends.ex on libmxnet.dll and these modules were found to be have errors.

The error is : Error opening fule. The system cannot find the file specified (2).

```
def sample_gaussian(mu, lv, batch_size, latent_z, ctx=mx.cpu()):
    epsilon = nd.random_normal(0, 1, shape=(batch_size, latent_z), ctx=ctx)
    sigma = nd.sqrt(nd.exp(lv))
    # sigma = nd.exp(lv * 0.5)
    z = mu + nd.multiply(sigma, epsilon)
    return z

class VAE(gluon.Block):
    def __init__(self, latent_z=100, batch_size=1, ctx=mx.cpu(),  **kwargs):
        super(VAE, self).__init__(**kwargs)
        with self.name_scope():
            self.enc = VAEEncoder(latent_z=latent_z)
            self.dec = VAEDecoder(latent_z=latent_z)
            self.latent_z = latent_z
            self.batch_size = batch_size
            self.ctx = ctx

    def forward(self, x):
        mu, lv = self.enc(x)
        z = sample_gaussian(mu, lv, self.batch_size, self.latent_z, self.ctx)
        y = self.dec(z)
        return y, mu, lv
```

@cjolivier01 No worries. I appreciate your assistance. However, this behavior could signal a serious bug (so perhaps someone more familiar with the python api should also take a look).


In short implementation 1 (file 1) defines the network in the same name space in which the training loop occurs; implementation 2 (file 2 <training loop> which imports file 3 <network definition>) has the network in a sub-namespace and runs the network in the main name space. The network and data is the same for both implementations and thus one would assume that both implementations would have the same result.

The point of implementation 2 is a rough first step to try an encapsulate / modularize the training process for distributed training e.g. so one can just focus on defining the network and say `trained_net = run(net=my_net, num_gpus=4)`.

We see that the distributed learning works well with implementation 1, where the run time decreases as the number of gpus increase.

We see the opposite in implementation 2, where the run time increase with the number of gpus (and the base run time for 1 gpu is also greater).

Hence I log this as an issue / bug. 

If mnist was just so small that no speed increase could be seen, then implementation should also show the same results as implementation 2.
